Ginzberg, A Commentary on the Palestinian Talmud 3 [New York 1941] 38 [Hebrew]) and the persistence of this version three times in PT (cf.yTaan 4:8, 68c; yYeb 13:1, 13b) indicates that it is the lectio difficilior and the correct version.

The name is recorded in the ancient Hebrew script, see Introduction 2.8.1. For the interchange of א and ה see Introduction 2.4.2.3. The form אבה is recorded on a First Temple west Semitic seal (CWSSSno. 1121). It is also recorded from Elephantine (TADAE 2, 2:2).
In Hebrew – מעניה. This may also mean “of Ma‘on,” see Introduction 3.2.6. An amora by the name of יוסי מעוני is mentioned in ySan 2:5, 20c (or יוסי מעוניה, Gen Rab 80:1).

person.note: The seal is from a museum in Berlin. It is written in square letters rather than the ancient Jewish script, making it later than the First Temple (from which time most Jewish seals date). It is clearly Jewish because of the symbols displayed on it. Lidzbarski, Ephemeris 1, 141, identified the symbols as similar to those on Hasmonean and other Jewish Second Temple coins.

This tannaitic tradition mentions him in the name of R. Yosi, and he is only further mentioned in tannaitic literature in a parallel in the Tosefta (tKel BM 7:2), see Introduction 7.5.1.2-3. In Lam Rab 31 he is described as Rabban Yohanan ben Zakkai’s nephew, and as present in Jerusalem during the siege. However, in bGit 56a this Jerusalemite is designated אבא סיקרא, and see under Siqra.
It has been suggested that this is the name of שאול’s mother, and indicates her place of origin (Batanaea). However, see Ilan, Nov Test 34 (1992) 27-8.
In tYT 3:8 his son is described as a shopkeeper (חנווני) in Jerusalem, see Introduction 7.5.1.1.

אבא שאול בן בטנית is recorded in tannaitic compilations such as the Mishnah. The name of his parent has a clear feminine ending ית. His son, bearing the name of the supposed grandfather (Botnit no. 1, see Introduction 3.1.1) with the feminine ending, is mentioned only in BT. He may be a Babylonian fiction, using papomony as their guide in choosing the name of their fictitious hero. And see also אליעזר בן הורקנוס (Hyracnus no. 8)and his son הורקנוס (Hyrcanus no. 9)and אלעזר בן פרטא (Parteh no. 1)and his grandson, אלעזר בן פרטא(Parteh no. 2). בטנית, however, may not have been a father name at all, but perhaps a nickname. Whether it was deliberately feminine is unclear.

note.ref: See above, n. 3. In tYT 3:8 his son is described as a shopkeeper (חנווני) in Jerusalem, see Introduction 7.5.1.1.

person.note: See Introduction 6.3.4.

The first name is unreadable, but it ends with ניה, and this indicates that בלעה is not really a name but probably a nickname see Introduction 6.1.1. MisgavQadmoniot33 (2001) 130 suggested that this is a variation of the biblical feminine בלהה but its position in the name makes it unlikely. It could also be interpreted as indicating the person’s place of origin – בלע – see Introduction 3.2.6, but the name is immediately followed by the words מן שכם (of Sechem) making this suggestion unlikely.
On the date of the Samaritan inscriptions, see Introduction 7.6.6.

So in PT. מעיין means “belly, womb, bowls” or “spring, fountain” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 816). מען is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 556). The Nabatean מעינו is also recorded (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 666). מעינא is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 95). Further on this name, see Klein,Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 340. For a discussion of the alternative יה and ין suffixes for this person, as also under Ba‘ya no. 3, and Arukh 2, 140.
So in bSan 44b, apparently referring to the same person, (Rashi, ad loc.). For the interchange of ה and א see Introduction 2.4.2.3.
In Hebrew – מוכס.

See Introduction 6.2. The context of this story (the hanging of witches in Ashkelon) is so legendary, that all figures who feature in it alone and nowhere else are suspect of being literary inventions.
See Introduction 6.1.1.
Described in this tradition as a contemporary of the “pairs,” see Introduction 7.5.2.

The form בענא is recorded in the Bible (e.g. 1 Kgs 4:12). Noth, IPRGN, 40, 119, thinks the name derives from the pagan theophoric בעל. בען and בענה are recorded as names for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 112). בענו is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 190). On the ין suffix see also Introduction 2.4.3.2. Here we have an example where this suffix is doubled.

Unlike the other figures in this late Midrash, Lieberman (Greek, 179-84) does not identify this person with any historical figure. He reads בעט בו יהודה instead of בעינן בן יהודה. I consider him a literary invention, see Introduction 6.2.3.

The name of this person is recorded in the documents both as בעיה and as בעין. On the two being alternative suffixes see Introduction 2.4.3.2. See above, n. 1. בעא means “to search, inquire, ask, examine” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 181). בעיא means “open wide, yawn” (Jastrow, ibid.) בעא as a name is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 11). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.4.

So in the Babatha archive (PYadin 26). Already Y. Yadin, Bar-Kokhba: The Rediscovery of the Legendary Hero of the Last Jewish Revolt against Imperial Rome (Jerusalm 1971) 249, assumed that the father (or family) name of Miriam in the Greek documents (Βειανοῦ), should be identified with the name בעין and בעיה in the Hebrew letters to יהונתן בר בעין, the commander of Ein Gedi at the time of the Bar Kokhba Revolt. This may easily explain why Miriam, Babtha’s co-wife, found refuge in the same cave with her brother. Whether her former rival was with them too, or whether Miriam had gained access to Babatha’s documents (e.g. via her daughter, Shelamzion) is a topic for novelists and playwrights, but not for historians.

This is the Greek transliteration of Jonathan’s father’s name in the Nahal Haver document published by Lifschitz. The difference between this transliteration and the previous one from the Babatha archive need not be interpreted as referring to a different person, but rather as two alternative scribal approaches to an unusual Semitic name. See also G. Wilhelm Nebe, “Die Beiden griechischen Briefe des Jonatan-Archivs in Engedi aus dem zweiten jüdischen Aufstand,” RQ 17 (1996) 276, who reads Βειανου here.

The identification of Γωρίονά τε Νικομήδους of Josephus, with נקדימון בן גוריון of rabbinic literature was suggested by Derenbourg, Essai, 281, n. 1, and universally accepted (i.e. he is Nicodemus no. 1’s son and Nicodemus no. 4’s father). The replacement of father and son is a common Josephan error, see Guria no. 2. In PT (yKet5:13, 30c) he is called שמעון בן גוריון, but this is clearly a mistake, as the parallels to this story show (tKet 5:9-10; Sifre Deut 305; bKet 65a; 66b-67a).
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

This is the way this warrior’s name is transliterated by Josephus. On this name see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 333; Schalit, Annual of the Swedish Theological Institute 4 (1965) 170. It probably suggests that Simon originated from a family of proselytes (גרים). The form Γωρᾶς is recorded on an Egyptian papyrus (Preisigke, NB, 82).

See above, n. 2. This is the way this warrior’s name is transliterated by Josephus. On this name see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 333; Schalit, Annual of the Swedish Theological Institute 4 (1965) 170. It probably suggests that Simon originated from a family of proselytes (גרים). The form Γωρᾶς is recorded on an Egyptian papyrus (Preisigke, NB, 82). Like the leader of the Jewish Revolt in 66-70 CE, this person too was probably given this name because he was a proselyte. See also DJD 2, 260.

On second names see Introduction 6.1.3. This second name is probably a description, indicating that this person is a proselyte. However, it appears with neither of the prerequisites of a nickname, i.e. with בן (son of) or ה (the) before it. Thus I choose to describe it as a second name.

See Introduction 6.2. This person is reputed in BT to have been the father’s name of a man who pursued all the prostitutes of the realm. The late date of the tradition and its context, within a large number of stories on Jewish sages and prostitutes, makes the tradition suspect. The only chronological indicator in the story is that R. Judah the Patriarch mourned him, indicating that he was earlier. However, this statement is not integral to the story. Thus I consider this figure legendary and do not include him in the statistics.

שלום ברת חוני בר יהונתן is important in Mur 30. Whether her father is to be identified with חנין בר יהונתן, who is her neighbour is difficult to decide. I have chosen to present them here as two separate persons, because this man is documented once as חוני and once as חני (in the inner and outer texts of the double document Mur 30) but never as חנין.

In the Mishnah, R. Yose is never designated בן חלפתא. A tanna by the name of חלפתא is also mentioned in the Mishnah as dated to the days of חנניה בן תרדיון (Hananiah no. 21 -mTaan 2:5), who flourished during the Bar Kokhba Revolt and died a martyr’s death in it. In the Tosefta ר' יוסי is also not mentioned as the son of חלפתא, but he is mentioned seven times as passing traditions in his name (tMS 1:13; tShab 13:2; tBB 2:10; tEd 2:9; tBek 2:19; tKel BM 1:5; tOhil5:8). Only in the Mekh. dRI, 176 is יוסי בן חלפתא mentioned. However a variant reading suggests יוחנן בן חלפתא. The Mekh dRI in general names ר' שמעון “ר' שמעון בר יוחאי” (twenty three times, Kosovsky, Mechilta, 45*-6* and see under Simon no. 51) and ר' יהודה, “ר' יהודה בר אלעי” (twice, Kosovsky, Mechilta, 17* and see under Judah no. 30). The form ר יוסי בן חלפתא first appears clearly in PT (twenty six times, e.g. yYeb 1:1, 2b and is then current in Palestinian midrashim, e.g. Gen Rab). In BT this form is also absent but the assumption that ר' חלפתא is יוסי’s father becomes apparent since all the traditions found in the Tosefta in which ר' יוסי testifies in the name of ר' חלפתא are now transmitted as: אמר ר' יוסי [אמר] אבא חלפתא (e.g. bBQ70a-b; bBB56b; bSan80a; bBek26a). However, in the Tosefta חלפתא is called אבא חלפתא only once (tSot8:6) and the transmitter of that tradition is ר' יהודה. The identification of חלפתא as the father of ר' יוסי is apparently based on bMeila 17b,where ר' יוסי identifies אבא חלפתא as his father. It is almost impossible to decide how reliable it is. And see also T. Ilan “Rabbi Yose Ben Halafta,” in Proceedings of the Fourth International Conference on Jewish Onomastics (in press).
Described in this tradition as a contemporary of ר' חנינא בן תרדיון (Hananiah no. 21), a martyr of the Bar Kokhba Revolt, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
In Hebrew – איש כפר חנניה.

Described in tKel BQ 4:17 as a contemporary of R. Hananiah (no. 21) ben Tardion’s son and daughter. This family all died out after the Bar Kokhba Revolt (Sifre Deut 346, n. 307), and see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
This is a late addition at the very end of the Mishnah, and he is probably an amora, but since he is mentioned in the Mishnah he is included in this corpus, see Introduction 7.5.1.4.
This added vocalization might give us a clue as to how the name was pronounced (Hilfata).

It is also worth noting that in tMS 4:5 a certain חליפא בן קרויא is mentioned (see Halifa no. 1 and Qeruya no. 1). What the relation between the two versions has not been commented upon and I make no independent judgment.

Probably called after his grandfather (Halafta no. 1), see Introduction 3.1.1. Alternatively, Halafta no. 1 was identified as his father’s father due to his name, see above, n. 2. In the Mishnah, R. Yose is never designated בן חלפתא. A tanna by the name of חלפתא is also mentioned in the Mishnah as dated to the days of חנניה בן תרדיון (Hananiah no. 21 -mTaan 2:5), who flourished during the Bar Kokhba Revolt and died a martyr’s death in it. In the Tosefta ר' יוסי is also not mentioned as the son of חלפתא, but he is mentioned seven times as passing traditions in his name (tMS 1:13; tShab 13:2; tBB 2:10; tEd 2:9; tBek 2:19; tKel BM 1:5; tOhil5:8). Only in the Mekh. dRI, 176 is יוסי בן חלפתא mentioned. However a variant reading suggests יוחנן בן חלפתא. The Mekh dRI in general names ר' שמעון “ר' שמעון בר יוחאי” (twenty three times, Kosovsky, Mechilta, 45*-6* and see under Simon no. 51) and ר' יהודה, “ר' יהודה בר אלעי” (twice, Kosovsky, Mechilta, 17* and see under Judah no. 30). The form ר יוסי בן חלפתא first appears clearly in PT (twenty six times, e.g. yYeb 1:1, 2b and is then current in Palestinian midrashim, e.g. Gen Rab). In BT this form is also absent but the assumption that ר' חלפתא is יוסי’s father becomes apparent since all the traditions found in the Tosefta in which ר' יוסי testifies in the name of ר' חלפתא are now transmitted as: אמר ר' יוסי [אמר] אבא חלפתא (e.g. bBQ70a-b; bBB56b; bSan80a; bBek26a). However, in the Tosefta חלפתא is called אבא חלפתא only once (tSot8:6) and the transmitter of that tradition is ר' יהודה. The identification of חלפתא as the father of ר' יוסי is apparently based on bMeila 17b,where ר' יוסי identifies אבא חלפתא as his father. It is almost impossible to decide how reliable it is. And see also T. Ilan “Rabbi Yose Ben Halafta,” in Proceedings of the Fourth International Conference on Jewish Onomastics (in press).
He is the son of R. Yosi, see Introduction 7.5.2.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
On the interchange of פ and ב, see Introduction 2.2.2.
On dating of the Masada documents see Introduction 7.8.
Always described in the sources as the father of ר' אושעיא, who is never described as his son.
In yNid 2:1, 49d he is described as a contemporary of R. Judah the Patriarch, see Introduction 7.5.2.
Described in this tradition as a contemporary of R. Judah the Patriarch, see Introduction 7.5.1.4.
In Hebrew – חסדי מחולן and חסדי עבד חני ... מן חלון. The document is a slave sale deed.
On dating of Qumran documents see Introduction 7.7.2.
In Sifra Negaim 1 he is designated בן חסמא.
On second names see Introduction 6.1.3.
In three mishnaic traditions (mBM 7:5; mAb3:18; mNeg 7:2) he is associated with Eleazar (no. 43) ben Azariah, a contemporary of Raban Gamaliel (mYad 4). See Introduction 7.5.1.2.
On second names see Introduction 6.1.3.
Described in this tradition as a contemporary of R. Judah the Patriarch, see Introduction 7.5.2.
This is an alternative reading of the name in some of the sources. It looks more like a place of origin than a personal name. See also Appendix.
It has been suggested that this is the name of יוחנן’s mother, but see Ilan, Nov Test 34 (1992) 28.
See Introduction 6.1.1.
Described in this tradition as an early contemporary of Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel, see Introduction 7.5.1.1.
See Introduction 6.1.1.
Described in tYK 1:22 as an officiating High Priest, see Introduction 7.5.1.1.
On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.
This is the Greek transliteration of this famous family name, recorded by Josephus, see Introduction 2.4.1.4.
See Introduction 6.1.2.
These are the dates of this family’s years of reign according to Josephus. On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.
In Hebrew – על המפתיחות.
See Introduction 6.1.1.
Associated with the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.1.1.
See Introduction 6.1.1.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
See Introduction 6.1.1.
Mentioned in this tradition in a genealogy in which the latest dated sages are late tannaim, see Introduction 7.5.2.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
See Introduction 6.1.1.
In this tradition he is described as a contemporary of Rabban Simon ben Gamaliel, see Introduction 7.5.1.3.
This is an alternative reading of the rebel leader’s name in rabbinic literature. On the interchange of א and ה see Introduction 2.4.2.3.

These are the four alternative forms this name has in the documents of this period found in the Judaean Desert. On the interchange of ש and ס see Introduction 2.2.5. On the interchange of א and ה see Introduction 2.4.2.3.On this name, see Milik, RB 60 (1953) 277-82.
This is the Greek form of the name preserved in the Judaean Desert documents. For the transliteration, see Introduction 2.1.2.8.

This is the form of the name preserved by Eusebius. On the Βαρ at the beginning of the name see Introduction 2.1.1.2.1. For the χ transliterating כ see Introduction 2.1.2.8. And see also Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 339.
See Introduction 6.1.1.
On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.
This information is only derived from BT (bYoma 83b).
Described in this tradition as a contemporary of R. Meir, see Introduction 7.5.2.
See Introduction 6.1.1.
See Introduction 7.5.1.4.
See Introduction 6.1.1.
On dating of the Masada documents see Introduction 7.8.
The documents are bilingual. So the name is spelt in PYadin 15, 20, 22. PYadin 19 has כתושיון.
The documents are bilingual. So the name is spelt in PYadin 18.
The documents are bilingual so his name is spelt in PYadin 11, 14, 17, 18, 19, 21, 22, 23, 24, 25, 26, 34.
The documents are bilingual. So the name is spelt in PYadin 15.
On second names see Introduction 6.1.3.
On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.

In BT this person is cited as such, but in PT (yTaan3:12, 67a) he is not cited as a tanna and he transmits a tradition in Aramaic, which may make his chronological placing suspect, see Introduction 7.5.2.
See Introduction 6.1.1.
Described in this tradition as a book similar to the sayings of Sirach. Grouping them together suggests antiquity. However, no other chronological indicator is available, see Introduction 7.5.2.
See Introduction 6.1.1.
See Introduction 7.5.1.4.

div.note: אבא means “father” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 2). On family members as names see Introduction 1.5.1. For the Aramaic name see Lipiński, Studies 1, 190-4. On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2. אבא is documented on a First Temple Hebrew seal (CWSSS no. 44); in 3rd C BCE Egypt (TADAE 4, 8:11); for amoraim (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 2-22; Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1-20); for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 8).
H. Eshel, DJD 38, 27, claims this is the only documented appearance of this name, although it is clearly a Hebrew one, of a biblical type.
On the ין suffix see Introduction 2.4.3.1. אבין is recorded as a name for amoraim (Kosovsky,Yerushalmi, 35-50; Kosowsky, Babylonico93-6); for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 18).

אבוקה means “torch” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 4). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.4.On the identification of this person with Hagira no. 1 and understanding his name as a midrash on his activities in the war with Rome, using burning torches, as described in Josephus, see M. Güdeman, “Josephus und die grosse Pesikta,” MGWJ 29 (1880) 132-4.

אבנא means “stone” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 7). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2. אבנא is documented as a female name in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 2). On this as a nickname see Naveh, Mas I, 66.

אגרא means “rent, wages, reward, profit” or “roof” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 14). אגרא is documented as an Idumean name (AOFCI, no. 90) and for an amora (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 103). אגרי is documented in Elephantine (TADAE3, 3.15, 4.5) and elsewhere in Egypt (ibid. 4, 18.8; 19.3). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.4.

אדי means “to swing, throw, pitch” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 16). See also Lipiński, Studies 1, 101-2. On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.1.3. It is recorded on an Aramaic, Persian-period seal (CWSSSno. 759); in 5th C BCE Egypt (TADAE3, 3.14); and in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 65). I assume this is a variation of the name אדא, which becomes popular among amoraim (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 55-9), where in most cases recorded the forms אדא and אידי are interchangeable. In BT the two seem separate (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 103-12 [אדא] and 153-5 [אידי]), but this may be the result of the different policies employed by these two concordances.

This name could derive from אדם. On the ון suffix see Introduction 2.4.3.1. Alternatively, אדמוני means “ruddy, gold-colored” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 17). The name אדימן is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 35a). Zunz, Namen, 8, views this as an innovative Hebrew name of the Second Temple period.

The forms אחיאם and אחומי are biblical (1 Chr 11:35; 1 Chr 4:2). For rabbinic etymology of these names see Harduf, Biblical Names, 15. For the י suffix, seeIntroduction 2.4.1.3.Variations on this name are found on First Temple Hebrew seals: אחאמה (CWSSSno. 54, 618) and אחימה (CWSSSno. 429). אחמה is documented as an Idumean name (AOFCI, no. 184). Note also the similarity to the name of the Persian Royal house, Haχāmaniš (̓Αχαιμένης – Justi, INB, 124). אחמנש as the Persian name Achaemenes is recorded in 5th C BCE Egypt (TADAE3, 3.8I).

אילא means “beak of a ship, buttress” or “grape worm,” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 48). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2. אילא is well documented for amoraim (Kosovsky,Yerushalmi, 84-91; Kosowsky, Babylonico, 157-8). איל is recorded for an Arab (Harding, ICPIANI, 89).

אלם means “mute” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 71). It is recorded as a name for an Arab (Harding, ICPIANI, 70). אילמי is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 74). Further on this name, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 330.

אני is documented as a name on a First Temple Semitic seal (CWSSS no. 1128). Another Hebrew seal bears the name אניהו, of probably the same root, with a picture of a ship on it (N. Avigad, “A Hebrew Seal Depicting a Sailing Ship,” BASOR 246 [1982] 59). It probably indicates a midrshic interpretation of the name at the time, obviously referring to the biblical word אני – “ship” (as in e.g. 1 Kgs 9:26). Avigad suggests that this name is short for אניא. The name אניא also appears as a second name of a tanna, Joshua who, according to PT, reports about the decisions of בית שמאי and בית הלל (Joshua no. 32 – yShab 1:4, 3c and Kosowki, Yerushalmi, 63), but in this case it probably indicates his place of origin - אונו. אני is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 81) and as an Egyptian name (Ranke, ÄPN 1, 2).

ארזא means “cedar” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 117). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2. ארזא is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 36). In Persian ̓́Αρζης is documented (Justi, INB, 42). Further on this name, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 330.
ארי means “lion” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 118).
בבלי means “Babylonian” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 137). Here it is used as a personal name rather than an ethnic designation. See also the name מצרי (Mesrai = Egyptian) below.

בוכרא means “first-born” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 145). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.1.3. בכרי is recorded as a name in the Bible (e.g. 2 Sam 20:1). Noth, IPRGN, 230, interprets it as deriving from בכר – young camel. בכר is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 114). בכרו is documented for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 180). In Persian the names Βόχρης and Buχārā are recorded (Justi, INB, 70-1). Further on this name, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 332.
בוניא means a sort of a bird in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 147). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.4.3. Zunz, Namen, 14, thinks this is a Greek name but he does not clarify which.

בטח means “a hollow, column-like receptacle of water” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 156). בן אבטיח is mentioned in yYoma 8:2, 44d. They may be identical. אבטיח means “melon” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 5). בטח is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 108). Further on this name, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 332.

בוטנא means “to be hollow, swell” or “pistachio nut” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 145). בטנא means “belly” and בטנאי is a kind of a bird in Aramaic (Jastrow, ibid. 158). בוטנה is also the region of Batanaea in Transjordan (ibid. 145). On the feminine suffix see Introduction 2.4.4.1. בטנת is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 109). In Persian Būtīn is also documented (Justi, INB, 74). Further on this name, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 334-5; 2, 262-3.

בלע in Hebrew means “to absorb, swallow, consume” (Jastrow,DTTBYML, 174). בלעה in Armaic means “the thing swallowed, choking fit” (Jastrow,ibid., 175). The name בלע is recorded occasionally in the Bible, e.g. Gen 36:32, and also as a place name, Gen 14:2.

בעא means “to search, inquire, ask, examine” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 181). בעיא means “open wide, yawn” (Jastrow, ibid.) בעא as a name is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 11). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.4.

ברוקא in Aramaic means “morning star” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 191). ברק is recorded as a name for Arabs, (Harding, ICPIANI, 102). ברוק is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 79). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2.

בשם in Hebrew means “perfume” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 199). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2. בשם is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 107); בשמה is documented for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 206, and M. C. A. Macdonald, “Personal Names in the Nabataean Realm: A Review Article,” JSS 44 [1999] 274). בסם means the same in Aramaic (Jastrow, ibid. 179). בוסם is documented as an Idumean name (AOFCI, no. 140). בסם is documented in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 77).
בתר as a name is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 92). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2. Further on this name see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 332.
גביה means “tall” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 206). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2. גביהא also appears as a name for amoraim (Kosowsky,Babylonico, 328).

גדגדה is mentioned in Deut 10:7 as a place name in Sinai, but the ה at the end may be a suffix indicating direction. גדגדניות means a kind of clover in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 210). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2. Further on this name, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 333; Reuveni, Lĕšonénu 2 (1930) 41.

גדיא means “kid” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 211). However, this name is probably derived from the Aramaic god of fortune, גד, as is the biblical name of גד the son of Jacob. Names deriving from it were popular, (e.g. CWSSS, nos. 12, 467, and others in that collection). The name is recorded for an amora (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 163). גדיא is documented as a name for Nabataeans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 214) and for the Palmyrans (Stark, PNPI, 81). Further on this name see Klein, Lĕšonénu 2 (1930), 269-70.

גדידה in Aramaic means “incision in the flesh,” or “cutting dates” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 212). ג'דד is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 154). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2. Zunz, Namen, 8, views this as an innovative Hebrew name of the Second Temple period.

גדיש in Aramaic means “pile, mound” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 212). Klein, reads this name גריש, see Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 334. גריש means “pounded beans” in Aramaic (Jastrow, ibid. 268). For the interchange of ר and ד see Introduction 2.7.4.

גובתא in Aramaic means “hill (or pit)” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 217). ג'בת is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 151). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2. For an interpretation of this name see Arukh2, 254.
The root גדע in Aramaic means “cut, chop, lop off” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 213). On this as a nickname indicating a person’s handicap, see Hachlili, EI 17 (1984) 198; DJD 2, 220.

גוריא means “cub, young lion” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 227). The name is recorded for amoraim (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 165; Kosowsky, Babylonico, 330). גור and גורו are documented as Idumean names (AOFCI, nos. 62-4, 69). גורא and גורי are documented in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 81). This is one of the rare cases in this corpus of a name serving for both males and females, see Introduction 1.5.2.

גירא means “lime” or “arrow” or “direct consequence” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 241-2). ג'ר is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 157). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2. “Proselyte” is גיור or גיורי in Aramaic (Jastrow, ibid. 236). The names here probably refer to the proselyte status of their bearers, and are thus nicknames. BT records גירא as the name of Antoninus’ daughter (bAZ 10b). This may also refer to her proselyte status.

גלגלא means “wheel” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 245). A similar name is recorded from the First Temple period (EBTHPN, 39). גלגל and גלגול are recorded names in Elephantine (TADAE 2, 3.1; 4.1). גלגל is documented as an Idumean name (AOFCI, nos 200-1). ג'לג'לן is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 164). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2. Further on this name see DJD 2, 157.
גלוסטרא/קלוסטרא in Aramaic means “a door bolt” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 246). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.4.
גני means “to cover, be covered” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 259). ג'ני is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 169).
גרוגרת in Aramaic means “dry fig” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 266). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.4.2.

גרידא means “arid land” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 268). ג'רד is recorded ass a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 158). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2. On this as a nickname, see Naveh, Mas I, 28.

גריס means “pounded grain” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 268), and see also under גדיש – Gadish above. ג'רס is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 158). See also DJD 2, 127. Alternatively, גרים as a nickname, probably indicating the conversion of its bearer to Judaism, is present in this corpus (see above, Gira no. 2). Perhaps the scribe intended to write a ם here. The two letters are graphically similar, see introduction 2.7.4.

גרמא means “bare twig, bone” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 270). On the ו suffix see Introduction 2.4.5.1, and PESSI 4: no. 68. In the Bible the name הגרמי is recorded (1 Chr 4:19) perhaps referring to a person’s place of origin or ethnicity. גרימו is recorded as a name for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 242). ג'רם is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 159). גרמי is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 82). Further on this name, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 347.

The root גרף in Hebrew means “to scrape, sweep” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 272). ג'רףis recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 159). The Nabatean name גרפו is recorded (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 257). On the suffix, see Introduction 2.4.2.4.On the other hand, a Greek provenance of the name is also possible. The forms Γράπτος (WGE, 260), Γρίπος, Γρίφος (LGPNII, 97), Γράψας (LGPNI, 111) as well as the feminine Γραφίς (WGE, 260) are recorded.

דהבא means “gold” in Aramaic(Jastrow, DTTBYML, 281). ד'הב is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 259). On this suffix see Introduction 2.4.1.3. דיהבא or דהבן is recorded for an amora (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 179). Further on this name, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 334.

דלעת means “gourd” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 311). דלע is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 242). On this suffix see Introduction 2.4.1.3. Further on this name, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 334.
דורדא means “sediment” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 289). דרדת is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 238). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2.

This name probably means that its bearer was of Damascus (Sifre Deut 1). Already in the Bible the form דרמשק occasionally replaces דמשק (2 Chr 16:2, 24:23, 28:5, 23). On the feminine suffix see Introduction 2.4.4.1.
דושא means “treading” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 284 and 291). For the suffix see Introduction 2.4.1.3.
דילוג means “leap, skipping” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 299). For the suffix see Introduction 2.4.1.3. Further on this name, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 334.

דינא means “law, decision, cause” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 301). The name דיני is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 83). On דיני and דינאי see Introduction 2.4.1.8. Further on this name, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 335.
דף/דפא means “board, plank, written column” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 316-7). דפא is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 241). For the suffix, see Introduction 2.4.1.3.

דמא means “to be dumb” or “to suspect” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 313). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2. In BT the name is assigned to a gentile – דמא בן נתינה from Ashkelon (e.g. in bAZ 23b). It is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 242). דומא is recorded in Elephantine (TADAE 2, 2:8).
דמליהו is recorded on First Temple Hebrew seals (CWSSS nos. 129-30; 476-81). דמל is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 243). For the suffix see Introduction 2.4.1.3.

דקנא means “beard” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 319). See also DJD 27, 44. On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.4. The name זקנא, which basically means the same, is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 86).

דרומא refers to a region in Judaea (e.g. Jastrow, DTTBYML, 322). דרם is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 239); and in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 84). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2. The meaning of the name is similar to the biblical תימן. Further on this name, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 335.

The root דרס means “tread, stamp” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 324). דרוסה is also the name of a coin and דרוסות means “pomace of dates” (Jastrow, ibid. 322). דרס is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 238). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.1.3. Further on this name, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 335-6.
הא means “worm,” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 328 and 335). Further on this name, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 336.
זוהמא means “filth” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 385). The name זהם is biblical (1 Chr 11:19). It is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 303). For the suffix see Introduction 2.4.1.3.

זומא means “broth, pulp” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 387). זם is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 301). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2. Zunz, Namen, 19, suggested the Greek name Ζωμυς here, but WGE records no such name. The nearest is Ζωμαλή (WGE, 448), which means soup, and see the next name (Zomlit).

זומיליסטרא represents the Greek ζωμάρυστρον (soup-ladle – Jastrow, DTTBYML, 387). Thus it was interpreted by Naveh, Mas I, 25. On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.4.1. However, זמלי is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 301).
זיוא means “splendor, glory” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 392). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.1.3.

זילא means “low valuation” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 394). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.1.3. זלי is recorded as a name in Elephantine (TADAE 2, 3.12). On the interchange of י and אי see Introduction 2.4.1.8.

זירוז means “quickening, urging on” in Aramaic ( Jastrow, DTTBYML, 397). Alternatively, the name זירוד is recorded for amoraim Kosowsky, Babylonico), 444. Perhaps a letter interchange has taken place.

זעירא means “small, young, tender, lesser” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 407). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2. זעירא is recorded often as a name for amoraim (Kosovsky,Yerushalmi, 213-32; Kosowsky, Babylonico, 448-50, and also 428-44 – זירא). זער is recorded from Persian Egypt (TADAE 3, 3.12). זערן is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 298).

זריקה means “sprinkling, thrusting” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 414). The name is recorded for amoraim (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 232-3; Kosowsky, Babylonico, 450-2). זרק is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 297). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2.

The root חבב means “to love” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 415-7). חבובא/חיבובא means “beloved” (Jastrow, ibid. 450). חבוב is recorded as a name in 3rd C BCE Egypt (TADAE 4, 8.6) and in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 87). The name חביבא is recorded for amoraim (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 234; Kosowsky, Babylonico, 452-3). חבב is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 173).

חגר means “lame” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 424). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.4. חגרא is recorded as a name for amoraim (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 237). חג'ר is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 177). חגירו is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 415). חגור is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 87). Further on this name, see Hachlili, EI 17 (1984) 197.

חדו means “joy” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 425). חדי is perhaps recorded as a name on a Phoenician First Temple seal (CWSSSno. 739). חד is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 178). The Nabatean חדדו is recorded (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 417). On the ו suffix as Nabatean, see Introduction 2.4.5.1. חדא is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 87).
חדקא means “thorn” in Aramaic(Jastrow, DTTBYML, 427). חדק is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 180). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2.

Jastrow, DTTBYML, 469, explains this name as follows: “m. (patron. of Σόλοι Κύπριοι) one from Soloe (Aligora), a sea-port town of Cyprus. Makhsh I, 3 Abba José ח' איש טבעון Ar. (ed. two words) of Soloe, a citizen of Tibon.” I have found no other explanation for this name.

Neither this name, nor any of its variants, are mentioned in the Hebrew Bible, but they clearly belong to the family of biblical names such as יוחנן and חנניה. This is particularly obvious with relation to Honi no. 1, son of Simon (no. 4)the Just (שמעון הצדיק) who is designated ̓Ονίαςby Josephus (AJ 12:44) and חוניו in BT (bMen 109b), but יוחנן in Sirach and נחוניון in PT (yYoma 6:3, 43d). A בן גדגודא is mentioned in the Mishnah both as נחוניא (mEd 7:9) and as יוחנן (mYeb 14.2, see Yohanan no. 26). Thus, the names are clearly of the same family and interchangeable. One may assume that חוני / חניה / חוניו are Aramicized, as befits the Second Temple period. On this name and נחוניה, see Schlatter, HN, 46. On the י suffix see Introduction 2.4.1.3.
חוצפא means “barefacedness, boldness, impudence” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 438). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.4.1.

The form חור may be of Egyptian provenance, associated with the Egyptian deity “Horus.” חור and חורי are certainly documented in Aramaic documents from Egypt in the Persian period (TADAE 2, 1.1, 3.7, 10, 11 [same person]; 3, 3.15 [x2; חורי], 4.6 [חורי]; 4, 5.35, 8.7, 9, 22.12 [חורי], 8.11, 18.17, 20.3, 22.18) and later (Ranke, ÄPN1, 245-6 and particularly 246, no. 15, which may be the name חורין). חורי is documented as an Idumean name (AOFCI, nos. 1, 3, 4, 25, 98, 137, 188, 190). חור is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 208). חרן is also recorded (Harding, ibid., 186). חורו is documented for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 424). For the ון/ן suffix, see Introduction 2.4.3.1.

חיטה means “wheat-grain” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 448). חט is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 192). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.4. חטייא is also recorded for an amora in midrashic literature, see Klein, Lĕšonénu2 (1930) 265, who rescued this person from the oblivion of the mss.

חטיל is mentioned in the Bible, e.g. Ezra 2:57. The form חטלו is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 428). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2. For the suggestion that חטלא is a place name see A. Demsky, “Qumran Epigraphy and Mishnaic Geography: The Identification of HTL’ with Hattulim (Menahoth 8:6),” Dead Sea Discoveries4 (1997) 157-61. Y. Yadin, The Message of the Scrolls(New York 1992) 62, suggested the name be read as הטלא – the young.

חייא means “life” or “midwife” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 454). The name was popular among amoraim (Kosovsky,Yerushalmi, 244-56; Kosowsky, Babylonico, 462-490). חיו is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 211). חיא is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 429). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2.
חכינא means “annulated snake” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 461). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.1.3.

חליפה means “replacement, substitution” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 469). This name is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 88). חלף is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 227). The Nabateans used חליפו (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 448). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2.
On this suffix see Introduction 2.4.1.3. Klein (Lĕšonénu 2 [1930], 264) claims, on the basis of ms. versions, that the name is חלכיס, indicating this person’s origin – Chalcis in Lebanon.

חלף means “reversion” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 472). This name, as well as חילפי and חלפיי, are recorded for amoraim (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 257). For Nabatean חלפי/חלפו is recorded (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 452-3).

חלפתא means “willow” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 472). The name is recorded for amoraim (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 259-60; Kosowsky, Babylonico, 492) and in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 89). חלפת is recorded as a name for Idumaeans (AOFCI, 99) and for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 227). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2.

חמא means “father-in-law” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 475). On family members as names see Introduction 1.5.1. The name is recorded for amoraim (Kosovsky,Yerushalmi, 260-2; Kosowsky, Babylonico, 494-8) and in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 89). חם is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 199). The Nabatean חמיו is recorded (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 461). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2.

This name may be identical with ̓Ανιλαίος mentioned in Josephus, AJ 18:314. It is also mentioned for several amoraim (Kosovsky,Yerushalmi, 263; Kosowsky, Babylonico, 501). חנל is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 206). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.1.3.

חסד means “grace, kindness, love, charity” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 486). חסד, חסדן and חסדה are recorded as names for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 188-9). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.1.3. The name חסדא was used by a Babylonian amora (Kosowsky,Babylonico, 529-54). In PT he is sometimes designated חסדי, חסדאי or חסדיי (Kosovsky,Yerushalmi, 281-4).

The root חסם means “withhold” or “to muzzle” or “to peal, scrape” or “bright and hard” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 488). חסם is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 189). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2.

The root חפן means “to take handfuls” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 492). חפני means “of (the town of) Haifa” (Jastrow, ibid). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.4.3. חפנם is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 195). Alternatively, the forms חפימן; חפימו are recorded in 5th C BCE Egypt (TADAE 2, 8:4; 3, 3:19, 4:2). It may be an Egyptian name (Ranke, ÄPN1, 237, no. 13; 2, 305, no. 3).

This name may be Egyptian, with the element “Horus” (Ranke, ÄPN 1, 249, no. 6). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.4.1. Alternatively, חרן is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 186). The Nabatean חרנו is also recorded (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 489). Further on this name, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 337.

The name is perhaps a variant of חרסון. A person named גביני בן חרסון is mentioned in Ecc Rab4:8, but not included in this corpus because the rabbis state that on his death the Persian King Belteshazzar was born, i.e. he is dated to the Persian period. חרסן means “earthen vessel, bed chamber” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 504).The name חרס is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 490). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.3. On the interchange of מ and נ see Introduction 2.5.3. Alternatively, this name may be Egyptian, with the element “Horus” (Ranke, ÄPN 1, 246). חרסיסי is recorded in 5th C BCE Egypt (TADAE 2, 8:11). Further on this name see Klein, Lĕšonénu2 (1930), 265.

The root חרק means “cat a gap, squeeze” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 506). The word חרקא means “edge, notch” (Jastrow, ibid). חרקן is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 184). Alternatively, this name may be Egyptian, with the element “Horus” (Ranke, ÄPN 1, 252, perhaps no. 9).

On the name see B. Maisler (Mazar), “Topographical Studies II: The Hasmonean Place of Origin,” BIES 8 (1941) 105-7 (Hebrew), who claims it derives from the biblical location חשם. On this suffix see Introduction 2.4.1.3.

טוטפת means “beads used as charms, frontlet” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 523). Alternatively, this name may be Egyptian, with the element “Thot” (Ranke, ÄPN 1, 409, no. 1). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.4.1. Further on this name, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 339.
טפזא means “rabbit” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 545). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.1.3.
יצף means “to be troubled, afraid” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 589).
כבל means “to chain” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 608). כבל is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 494). On the ין suffix see Introduction 2.4.3.1.

כהנא means “priest” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 615). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2. The name is recorded for amoraim (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 472-4; Kosowsky, Babylonico, 959-70). Further on this name, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 339.
On various interpretations of this name see Milik, RB 60 (1953) 277-82. On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2.

This name is explained as deriving from the verse “כי דור תהפוכות המה” (Deut. 32:20). This, however, is clearly a false etymology. כדור means “ball, globe” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 613) and cf. also the name גלגולא – Galgula. כדר is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 496). The name may also be of Greek extraction with the element δῶρα in it (an element also present in biblical names: מתת; מתן).

כיפר means “forgive, atone” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 661). כפר is documented as a name on several west Semitic First Temple seals (CWSSS nos. 1097, 1096-7) and for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 501). כפירו is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 577.

Probably associated with the Babylonian god נבו. The name כנבו appears on an Aramaic First Temple seal (CWSSS n. 803). On the ון suffix see Introduction 2.4.3.1. See, however on this as a nickname, Naveh, Mas I, 28.
כתש means “to crush, to pound, to beat” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 682-3). On the יון suffix, see Introduction 2.4.3.1.

לודאה means “Lyddan” or “gladiator” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 695). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2. Perhaps this לודא is identical with ר' לודה mentioned in yTaan3:12, 66a. If not, this is another occurrence of this name. לדא is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 514). The Nabatean לודן is also recorded (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 592).
לענה means “bitterness, wormwood” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 715). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.2.

לקיש means “slow, late, late rain, late-born” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 719). לקיש is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 520). It is also found for the famous amora Simon ben Laqish or Resh Laqish (ריש לקיש – Kosovsky,Yerushalmi, 487-501; Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1711-40). Further on this name, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 380; 2 (1930) 265-6.
